Architecture.title: ‚öôÔ∏è Project Architecture
Architecture.subtitle: Current Solution
Architecture.clientSide: The client side is built with Next.js (React, TypeScript, Tailwind CSS, next-intl). Here, users select their country, number of days, and language. The request is sent via Axios to the backend API.
Architecture.backendSide: The backend is powered by FastAPI (Python). It retrieves Points of Interest (POIs) from a SQLite database, each with coordinates, visit duration, and a "nice score".
Architecture.gaIntro: To compute the itinerary, we use a Genetic Algorithm (GA). The GA simulates evolutionary optimization: multiple random routes are generated, evaluated, and iteratively improved. Fitness is based on:

gaPoints.balanceLimits: Balancing daily limits (about 8 hours of activity per day)

Architecture.gaResult: The best path found after several generations is returned as a JSON response, with details like day index, travel minutes, visit minutes, cumulative time, and translations.

flow.2: Frontend sends the trip request (country, days, language) to the FastAPI backend.
flow.3: The backend retrieves Points of Interest (POIs) and metadata from the SQLite database.
flow.4: Retrieved POI data, including translations, is returned to the FastAPI processing module.
flow.5: FastAPI sends the POI data and trip parameters to the Genetic Algorithm (GA), which computes the optimal itinerary (maximizing score while minimizing travel time).
flow.6: GA results are returned to FastAPI, which selects the final content in the requested language.
flow.7: The response is sent back to the Next.js frontend, where the itinerary is displayed to the user.

Architecture.awsIntro: To scale the project for more users and larger datasets, we plan to migrate into the AWS Cloud ecosystem:

awsPoints.1: AWS API Gateway ‚Äì secure entry point for client requests
awsPoints.2: AWS Lambda ‚Äì serverless functions running GA computations
awsPoints.3: Amazon RDS / Aurora ‚Äì scalable database replacing SQLite
awsPoints.4: AWS S3 ‚Äì storage for images and static data
awsPoints.5: AWS CloudWatch ‚Äì monitoring, logging, and performance metrics
awsPoints.6: AWS SageMaker (future) ‚Äì advanced ML/AI models for personalized itineraries

Architecture.awsOutro: This cloud-native architecture ensures high availability, global reach, and enterprise-grade security.
Architecture.futureIntro: Beyond infrastructure, we aim to continuously improve the user experience and provide smarter travel planning features:

futurePoints.1: User activity tracking ‚Äì learn from past itineraries to offer more relevant suggestions
futurePoints.2: Preference-based planning ‚Äì allow users to set trip pace, budget, or themes (history, food, nature)
futurePoints.3: Multi-country trips ‚Äì support itineraries across several EU countries in one plan
futurePoints.4: Collaboration features ‚Äì share and co-edit plans with friends or family
futurePoints.5: Offline availability ‚Äì export itineraries for use without internet access
futurePoints.6: Gamification ‚Äì reward users for exploring new places or sustainable travel choices

1.q: Why use a Genetic Algorithm instead of Dijkstra or A*?
1.a: Traditional algorithms work well for shortest paths but struggle with multi-objective optimization (scenic score + time limits + daily structure). GA offers flexibility and near-optimal solutions quickly.

2.a: SQLite is lightweight, portable, and perfect for prototyping. As the project grows, we‚Äôll move to a scalable cloud database like PostgreSQL on AWS Aurora.

3.a: We envision personalized itineraries powered by machine learning, live integration with transport APIs, and multi-user collaborative planning, all running on cloud-native infrastructure.

4.q: Can I plan trips across multiple countries?
4.a: Yes ‚Äî future versions will support multi-country itineraries, optimized for border crossings, cultural themes, and transport efficiency.

5.a: We plan to introduce an offline mode where itineraries can be saved to your device and accessed without internet connectivity ‚Äî ideal for traveling abroad.

6.a: By analyzing user preferences and past choices, the system will suggest itineraries that match your travel style ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs food, history, nature, or nightlife.

7.q: Is sustainability considered in the trip planning?
7.a: Absolutely. Our planner encourages eco-friendly travel options such as walking, biking, or trains and highlights destinations that promote sustainability and local culture.

8.a: We follow GDPR-compliant practices. User data is never sold and is stored securely. In the future cloud setup, we will add end-to-end encryption and user-controlled data deletion.
